snippet: A new study on whether access to computerized patient records lowers medical costs is an important cautionary note to the federal government.
abstract: Editorial draws attention to study that found office-based physicians who have access to electronic records of patient care are more likely to order additional tests than doctors who rely on paper records; maintains support for the adoption of electronic records, but says study is a reminder that even with such records, doctors will need to be pushed to rein in excessive testing.
lead_paragraph: A new study on whether access to computerized patient records lowers medical costs is an important cautionary note to the federal government.
